issue.title: TabNet training not working with PyTorch version of Ludwig
issue.body:
Tested on MacBook Pro i9 and M1.

TabNet does not appear to be training in Ludwig using PyTorch.  Tried higgs boson example as well as mushroom edibility.

Observed:

- Loss does not decrease between epochs
- AUC is stuck at 0.5 or close

Desired Behavior:

- Training TabNet with Torch should converge; loss should decrease as model trains
- Results with PyTorch should match Tensorflow reference results

For example, on the mushroom edibility experiment in the [experiments repo](https://github.com/ludwig-ai/experiments)
`experiments/automl/validation/mushroom_edibility/train_tabnet_sanity_laptop.py`

Loss after 1 epoch (Ludwig 0.4, TensorFlow)
```
Took 42.9332s
╒═════════╤════════╤════════════╤═════════════╕
│ class   │   loss │   accuracy │   hits_at_k │
╞═════════╪════════╪════════════╪═════════════╡
│ train   │ 0.6961 │     0.6016 │      1.0000 │
╘═════════╧════════╧════════════╧═════════════╛
```


Loss after 1 epoch (Ludwig 0.5.dev0, Torch)
```
Took 1.5725s
╒═════════╤════════╤════════════╕
│ class   │   loss │   accuracy │
╞═════════╪════════╪════════════╡
│ train   │ 0.9712 │     0.5032 │
╘═════════╧════════╧════════════╛
```


Run logs for comparison:
[Ludwig_0.4_tensorflow_mushroom.log](https://github.com/ludwig-ai/ludwig/files/7731209/Ludwig_0.4_tensorflow_mushroom.log)

[Ludwig_0.5.dev0_pytorch_mushroom.log](https://github.com/ludwig-ai/ludwig/files/7731210/Ludwig_0.5.dev0_pytorch_mushroom.log)

body: @dantreiman One thing I would make sure to confirm is first of all the optimizer. Please doublecheck that the same optimizer, with the same parameters is used (also doublecheck the parameters themselves, as sometimes they may be one the flip of the other, like dropout -> dropout_rate). If big differences still persist, I would try using a regular sgd optimizer, in my experience Adam behaves VERY differently in TF and PT (in TF it converges super fast but is really unstable and bouncy, in PT it seems more stable and slower to converge, ut it's just anecdotal). Finally, I would also doublecheck initializations, if they happen correctly for all modules in PT and if the ranges and distributions of the weights after initialization are roughly similar.

Anyway, results look different, in particular model1 training, but it's difficult o set a bar really. I'd say the goals here should be to:
1. make sure there are no errors in model building, loss computation (for instance regularization and other special losses like the ones in tablet), optimization and initialization
2. make sure we are not losing performance
3. make sure that in the case where we do, maybe wiggling a bit parameters and config compensates it

Although it should not be the case, little implementation discrepancies between the frameworks may result in different outcomes, and we should be ok with that, but also try to limit issues. Does this make sense to you @dantreiman ?

Good ideas!  I added a config that trains with SGD, learning rate 0.001, no weight decay or regularization.  Results below.


One thing I notice is that model2 uses zscore normalization in the preprocessing of a few of its features.  model 1 does not have feature normalization.  I wonder if something is different in the working on feature preprocessing or batch norm - since the model with normalized features has the least divergence between torch and tensorflow.



Ludwig 0.4:

![learning_curves_tf_accuracy](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/687280/146981603-c81543f6-9e9d-42c9-98cb-19d08a5eae2c.png)
![learning_curves_tf_loss](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/687280/146981606-02373f1c-c2b2-44e4-8f1e-12181a6166f4.png)


Ludwig 0.5dev:

![learning_curves_torch_accuracy](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/687280/146981621-c466257c-fcd8-4d27-a2de-04eec8dc1220.png)
![learning_curves_torch_loss](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/687280/146981625-38432866-8caf-446a-b7c1-78de1312aaa5.png)

issue.title: Inconsistent learning rates shown in output when specifying learning rate in config
issue.body: When specifying the learning_rate parameter in the training section of the config, `description.json` shows a different default learning rate in the optimizer section: config.yaml: description.json: Expected behavior is that there is one learning rate, and if it is specified in the config it should match that.

body: Zooming in on model 1 only: Train Stats: PyTorch orange, tensorflow red: Test Stats: PyTorch red, Tensorflow blue. Note: - Step training loss appears to show that PyTorch converges to a lower train loss than Tensorflow, but the epoch loss is higher on every epoch. Have we changed the way we smooth or aggregate the loss? - Accuracy is a close match, but AUC is not. Why? Perhaps we should plot the final ROC curves.
#1659 Fixes the chart above.  Turns out epoch loss running average was not being reset between epochs, so the red and orange lines of epoch loss were cumulative averges.

issue.title: TabNet training issues
issue.body:
- Fixes loss metrics using MeanMetric not resetting.  Descendants of MeanMetric (any LossMetric) were not getting reset between epoch, and thus were reporting a global cumulative average, not an epoch average.

- Changes LudwigModule's `_callable_losses` property to just `_losses`, and changes `add_loss` to `update_loss`.  This is only used for one thing: TabNet's Sparsity loss term.  In tensorflow, `add_loss` made sense because the call operator is only really called once to build the graph, as opposed to Torch's `forward` method which is called on every forward pass.  So, now we update the sparsity loss on every forward pass and include it in the overall train loss.

- Sets model into evaluation mode when generating predictions  using `model.train()` and `model.eval()`.  TorchModule's `training` property controls whether batch norm updates its running statistics, and whether drop out drops channels.  If we generate predictions while `training` is True, the predictions will be wrong if dropout or batch norm are used.
